title: Senna the Support adc.
body:
Welp. We've been there before. An adc used as support.

However, we've never EXPLICITLY been there before with the _intent._

Now..... I have an opinion, and many readers aren't going to like it or want to agree with me..... but....

#I think that the Senna Experiment is going to fail.

Don't get me wrong. I like the concept. I like Senna's design a lot myself.

#BUT

Right now, bot lane meta is absolutely destroyed. Duo Mage bot lanes are often more successful than actual adc bot lanes. 
In other words, ...... I'm concerned that the concept is dead in its tracks.... because even if we do duo ADC bot, they will be outranged, and outkitted by longer and longer range duo synergies.

It seems like right now...... every 500-600 range adc is hard capped in how much they can control their own lane. Kai Sa, Vayne, Lucian... all generally suffer one thing: Existing in a world where both support and the other adc outrange them. All three, on their own, are generally considered strong kits.... but have you ever noticed that the higher elo Lucian goes, the less he gets to poke, and the more he gets boxed under his own turret? Or, that Kai Sa's lane phase is generally slow, and the pace is controlled by how aggressive and how many gaps the other team gives her? Vayne has been a late game champion for at least 3 seasons now.

If Senna has any sensible range as an "Adc Support," she too is going to be subject to these rules of how adcs work.

Furthermore, (and this is a hypothesis) IF Senna actually has support capability, she's going to be broken out of the box, not necessarily favoring wins, _**but in the fact she will be difficult to balance.**_ In other words, she will be weighing any supporting abilities in her kit (like an ult that blocks and reflects a shield) against the fact she needs to compensate her adc identity with a support's ability to fight at range and help peel an opposing adc. That's a tall order to do correctly.

League will have added a new romance to play and a new champion, but a whole new can of worms in the form of balancing nightmares. She very well could become the next Karma: Can't be allowed to be strong in any one feature, so left to suffer in general.

Honestly every 'gimmick' for the past couple releases have all been balance nightmares or balance failures.

Kalista - Hopping = hard to balance
Yuumi - Attachment gimmick = hard to balance
Kayn - Transformation = hard to balance (at least initially)
Pyke - Hypercarry assassin support??? = hard to balance
Sylas - Ult stealing = hard to balance
Ivern - Support jungler = hard to balance
Yuumi again - Attachment gimmick again = my god Riot

Like I get it, I do like Riot taking risks and trying out new stuff, but in all of these gimmicks, every time there's a broken aspect of it that needs fixing, instead of fixing it, they try to force buffing/nerfing it to be viable (or at least just barely viable)

In most cases these issue are sorted by removing mechanics but they seem sometimes reluctant to do that as it would hurt the champs identity. Took a long time for them to admit Akali's W was a bit much. Riot shouldn't look at how it feels to play the champ, they should always look at how it feels to play against it (as in each game 1 person plays it while 5 play against it). 

Remove Yuumi's damage, she's too safe to deal damage. Remove Pyke's extra gold, he doesn't need it, he's a support. Remove Sylas most of his kit, just because potentially he has no ult doesn't mean he needs all his abilities to do everything else.

The start of the issues was Camille. Legit look at her first kit. Adaptive shield to help in lane when going in against an enemy, true damage auto reset that procs with sheen. 90% area of effect slow that heals her and does % HP damage. Dash for potentially 1200 units that area of effect stuns on hit and gives her attack speed. An ult that means the enemy literally cannot escape (breaking the unstoppable game mechanic) that gives her invulnerability frames and gives her % HP magic damage damage. She has literally everything in her kit that you'd ever need and they cost pretty much nothing. And most of this remains just at tuned levels. The mechanics remain the same.

I'm tired of mages bot lane in general.

Riot never rebalanced them when they did the Sightstone changes. 

Before mage supports were a risk to play consistently into every match up because AP damage items were expensive and therefore unreliable because supports get no farm and generally have the least amount of gold. They're usually the last to hit level 18 as well.

Mage supports were always loathed by those that didn't play them, but outside of Zyra occasionally becoming OP, they generally relied on overwhelming an inexperienced bot lane early on. ~~Of course we still have to deal with Morgana's deceptive Q hitbox in 2019, which still results in her being one of the most banned champions, thanks Riot. Happy 10th.~~

Anyways, what they had going for them was a lot of cheese, but now they have no drawbacks because they can poke and poke while making bank as well as get vision with Frost Fang. 

I'm not saying that mages bot lane gotta go, but they do need to be toned down and become a little more risky to play so that there's some skill required to play them because a mage support that gets the lane ahead is one of the most oppressive situations you can be in bot lane.

The problem is how to do that without actually deleting them from play. Most mages with a few exceptions DO struggle in bot lane. Morgana (I know you hate her) generally DOES die in bot lane because her fight is linear and predictive, and her auto attack range is low, and her W damage low. The ones that generally are considered toxic in Bot are actually those who:

1) Hook like Swain/Morde
2) Outrange everyone in the game (Ziggs/Xerath)
3) Has spammability/and significant damage output AND range (Vel Koz)

Senna is a marksman. She's so far not been pitched as an ADC. There's a difference between just being a marksman and being an attack damage carry. They can be mutually exclusive of each other. So let's not pre-emptively muddy the water here by confusing marksman and ADC. Senna is a support who is a marksman, she is not a support who is an ADC. That would be Pyke. He is explicitly designed to be an attack damage carry and a support simultaneously.

Bot lane already gets less XP than mid? They do it because {{item:3098}} + CC kits = more gold and accumulated control over a game than mid does. It's effortless gold vs contested gold and poor mana management and resourceless assassin mids.

Vel Koz mid: Gets jungle ganked or approached from a side alley.
Vel Koz Support: Near free spam of skills that if they hit almost guarantees a kill.

Brand Mid: has to throw a ton of auto attacks, risking counterpoke
Brand Support: Just has to focus champions and can stay almost entirely safe from poke.

Vel Koz + Morgana Bot = GG. Have to dodge 3 linear skill shots every time they volley, which is almost impossible.

Xerath Bot: Double the DH stacks, almost risk-less farm.

None of this has ANYTHING to do with bot getting too much XP. It has to do with their lives being far simpler as supports. Period.

>None of this has ANYTHING to do with bot getting too much XP.

Yea, it does.
Think about if for a second, if generally bot lane is under the average level of your team, that's the scaling and damage they don't have in levels over a champion that can gank them. The dynamic of bot lane doesn't change much on paper but relative to the other lanes, you can't demolish the opponents turret and come out stronger than a mid or top laner and contest their objectives with relative ease once your "stronger" lane wins.

This means that Marksmen definitely outscale bot support mages given that they can't pocket as much gold with poke as they would being mid lane, getting kills and CS.

If you try to reduce "bot mage" damage, you inevitably end up cutting the legs off both Support and Marksman counterparts. Marksman mage counterparts would not have a reason to be played if their damage is lower and outscaled by a Marksman. Support mages would fade away if their damage gets outscaled from poke, only being reduced to being CC bots.

Mage supports are, by my prediction, going to fall out of favor. They are reducing duo exp gain, which will further hinder the scaling of mage supports. Since they rely on scaling more than traditional supports, traditional supports will be more sought after.

It'll reduce the scaling of both adcs and supports by a flat rate if they do so, so relative to the position, Mage would STILL be superior if they were to do so. When they adjust XP gains, it's not like they say...... "Nami can have 63 XP on a large minion and Vayne can have 73 XP." They say "If there are two units in proximity, they both get a 25% XP reduction."  In other words, Brand will STILL get the same XP as Nami, yet he would be more useful than Nami, because Nami relies on 1) getting to her ult 2) scaling heals and 3) get her HP up (which is abysmal and often gets 1 shot as is)

But I’m saying they will scale less in the scheme of the entirety of the game. Mage supports are picked for their scaling into late game, but not in relations to their enemy laners alone.

The Brand support will scale less than the other lanes— lesser than a brand support already does. So he will encounter his spike later than say the actual mid-laner and top-laner, thus being less effective than a support that does not rely as heavily on scaling. They will have a higher impact in relations to the entire team.
